steps.name: Spot the Story
steps.instruction: Identify the narrative your brain is trying to prove right now.
steps.tagline: Observe the prediction. Don't collapse your life.

obstacle.false_belief: If I see the real story, I'll have to admit I've been wrong about everything—and that will unravel my entire identity.
what_they_dread: Exposing themselves as a fraud or failure
Dismantling the competence they've built and starting over
Having to blow up their life (quit the job, leave the relationship, admit they've been 'living a lie')
Confirming their worst fear: 'I've wasted years building the wrong life.'
obstacle.truth_they_dont_know: Spotting the story doesn't mean you were wrong—it means you were loyal to old data. The story was adaptive once; now it's just outdated. Seeing it clearly doesn't obligate you to tear everything down; it gives you the option to update the architecture without detonating your life.

false_actions: Confess to everyone that they've been 'faking it'
Relive every moment they 'got it wrong'
Justify or defend the old story
Generate a perfect replacement narrative in the same breath

true_action.description: My brain has been running this prediction. Here's the evidence it's been collecting. That makes sense given X, Y, Z. Now I see it. No confession. No collapse. Just clarity.

steps.name: Name the Feeling
steps.instruction: Label the emotion fueling the spiral: shame, fear, guilt, or inadequacy.

obstacle.false_belief: If I name the feeling, it will consume me. I'll fall apart, lose control, or prove I'm as weak as I've always feared.
what_they_dread: That naming shame or fear means becoming it—that acknowledgment = surrender
That if they let themselves feel inadequacy or guilt fully, the emotion will be bottomless and they'll never come back up
That naming it out loud (even to themselves) makes it 'real' in a way that can't be undone
That emotions are proof of weakness, and naming them confirms they don't belong in high-stakes rooms
That once they start feeling, the floodgates open and they lose the composure that's been keeping everything together
obstacle.truth_they_dont_know: Naming the feeling de-fuses you from it. It moves the emotion from 'I AM ashamed' to 'Shame is present.' That shift alone reduces the hijack by 40–60%. The feeling doesn't grow when you name it—it loses its grip. You're not weak for feeling it. You're high-resolution. The feeling has been running the whole time; naming it just puts you back in the driver's seat.

false_actions: Sit with the feeling for hours in painful excavation
Cry or 'release' it in some performative cathartic way
Trace it back to childhood wounds
Justify why they feel this way
Fix or eliminate the feeling immediately

true_action.description: The feeling fueling this loop right now is [shame / fear / inadequacy / guilt]. That's it. Label it. Move on. The loop loses 50% of its power the moment it's named.

steps.name: Reveal the Prediction
steps.instruction: Uncover what outcome the replay is trying to protect you from.
steps.tagline: See the prediction. Test it against reality.

obstacle.false_belief: If I uncover what I'm really afraid of, I'll have to face that it's true—and I won't be able to handle it.
what_they_dread: That the prediction their brain is making is accurate—and if they see it clearly, they'll have to accept it as inevitable
If I admit I'm afraid of being rejected, it's because I'm actually unlovable
If I admit I'm afraid of failing, it's because I don't actually have what it takes
That revealing the prediction means admitting the fear is rational, not paranoid—which makes it unsolvable
That once they see what the replay is protecting them from, they'll realize how fragile their entire life structure is
That the prediction will sound so 'small' or 'stupid' that they'll be embarrassed by how much power it's had over them
That revealing it = having to immediately fix it or disprove it, which feels impossible in the moment
obstacle.truth_they_dont_know: The prediction is your nervous system's best guess based on old data—it's not a prophecy. Seeing it clearly doesn't make it true; it makes it testable. Once you see the prediction, you can ask: 'Is this still accurate? What evidence contradicts it?' Most predictions sound like: 'If I do X, I'll lose Y.' But when you map it, you often find that X has already happened multiple times without losing Y. The prediction is running on outdated firmware.

false_actions: Go back and analyze every past instance where the fear 'came true'
Build an airtight case for why the fear is irrational
Eliminate the fear before moving forward

true_action.description: The outcome this replay is trying to protect me from is: [losing respect / being exposed as incompetent / being abandoned / failing publicly / etc.]. Once it's visible, the brain can start testing it against current reality instead of replaying the past to 'solve' for it.
